title: Water supply at Los Alamos during 1974

Note on the significance of synthetic fuels and the role of nuclear energy as a source of supply
Analysis of a Helium Pressurant Loading System for a Fluid Supply System (FSS)
Regulating voltage with just one quad IC and one supply
The Psalm-Singer's Amusement
Ammonia supply/demand balance uncertain
The Sevilla Water Supply
items.abstract: <jats:p>Incorporated into Sevillas water‐supply management policy is the use of a specially designed meter to record separately day‐ and night‐time use with a reduction specified for off‐peak hours. Justification for such a reduction and other administrative procedures are explained in the following article.</jats:p>

title: Afforestation, Catchment Protection and Water Supply Demands
Water‐Supply Problems and Developments in Indonesia
items.abstract: <jats:p>The Republic of Indonesia does not have a quality water‐supply system for its rapidly expanding urban centers. As urban expansion continues to accelerate, it is imperative that water‐utility systems be developed and maintained. This article examines two five‐year plans that the Indonesian government has devised for attaining systems of water‐utility operations for its swelling cities.</jats:p>

title: Water‐Supply Dam for Abha Town
items.abstract: <jats:p>In a very arid country like Saudi Arabia, the problem of water supply is acute. The Saudi government is tapping all possible sources of water to provide potable supplies for its people. Thus it has recently constructed a large water‐supply dam on <jats:italic>wadi</jats:italic> Abha for the expanding town of Abha.</jats:p>

title: Development of Water Supply in Metropolitan Manila
items.abstract: <jats:p>The author described action being taken to ensure that Manila's water supply is of consistently high quality and to provide sufficient quantities of water for an anticipated population increase. Some problems peculiar to that country are also pointed out.</jats:p>

title: An Inexpensive Pulsed Power Supply for a Septum Magnet
High-speed isotachophoresis: current supply and detection system
Systems evaluation of village water supply and treatment in Thailand
items.abstract: <jats:p>A systematic evaluation was made of 165 village water supply and treatment systems in Northeast Thailand for studying problems involved in the design, construction, operation, administration, and financing of such systems. The evaluation included 1 year of field data collection covering system operation by village operators. This is believed to be the first such evaluation of the effectiveness of a rural water supply development program. Findings include quantification of strengths and weaknesses pertinent to management, and recommendations are developed for guiding governmental agencies operating such programs and international agencies participating in their planning and financing.</jats:p>

title: Development and Management of Water Supply in Taiwan
items.abstract: <jats:p>Like other underdeveloped countries of southeast Asia, Taiwan has traditionally been lacking in essential services such as a quality water supply to its population. Under the auspices of the Republic of China and with the assistance of more highly industrialized nations, the Provincial Government of Taiwan has implemented a long‐range program to improve its inadequate water‐supply system. Rapid population growth dictates the exigency of this plan.</jats:p>

title: A controllable secondary multikilowatt dc current source with constant maximum power factor in its three phase supply line
PRESCHOOL SUPPLY AND DEMAND IN THE UNITED STATES
A Comprehensive Study of the Tocks Island Lake Project and Alternatives. Part C. Analysis of Alternatives to Supply Resource Needs
Evaluation of the Benefits of Rural Water Supply Projects in Tanzanian Villages
items.abstract: <jats:p>Empirical data collected from a field study conducted in fifteen Tanzanian villages were evaluated to determine the effects of improved water supplies. The results are used to determine priorities of development objectives and to formulate methods of project planning and evaluation.</jats:p>

title: The effect of cold air inhalation on again pectoris and myocardial oxygen supply.
items.abstract: <jats:p>Inhalation of cold air (-20 degrees C) for four minutes provoked angina pectoris in four of 17 coronary disease patients at rest and in four of seven of the patients while they were paced at a heart rate level which was subanginal at room temperature. The cold air did not increase myocardial O2 consumption significantly, and the accompanying changes in systemic hemodynamic factors known to influence myocardial O2 consumption were minor. Coronary blood flow determined by the xenon clearance method did not change significantly. In 18 patients, cold air inhalation for 1 1/2 minutes caused no detectable constriction of coronary arteries visualized arteriographically. We conclude that angina pectoris induced by breathing cold air cannot be explained satisfactorily by a concurrent increase in myocardial work and O2 consumption. Although neither large coronary artery constriction nor generalized coronary arteriole constriction seem to be involved, some other specific effect of cold air inhalation on coronary vasomotion, perhaps affecting collaterals or coronary blood flow distribution, is suspected.</jats:p>

title: An Elaboration of the Relationship Between General Hospital Bed Supply and General Hospital Utilization
container-title: Journal of Health and Social Behavior

title: Total Approach for the Bogota, Colombia, Water Supply
items.abstract: <jats:p>A systems‐analysis study for the Bogota, Colombia, region included application of simulation, linear programming, and dynamic programming which have been vital to a multidisciplinary approach in selecting a recommended plan for municipal water supply, irrigation, and hydroelectric developments</jats:p>

title: General Aspects of Water Supply and Treatment in Ontario
items.abstract: <jats:p> This paper deals with various sources of water supply in Ontario and the methods and relative difficulties of treating these sources. Sources include the Great Lakes, southern Ontario rivers and groundwater, and northern rivers and lakes. Distinctive characteristics with respect to hardness, turbidity, colour, chemical constituents, and biological and bacteriological content require specific treatment approaches for the provision of safe and palatable supplies. The effects of urbanization and industrial development are also discussed.The current approach to water treatment in Ontario is reviewed, as well as some of the historical developments leading up to the present state-of-the-art. Future requirements are touched on. Provincial water quality objectives are described and compared with international drinking water standards. </jats:p>

title: Relationship between adenosine concentration and oxygen supply in rat brain
items.abstract: <jats:p> Since adenosine is present in normal brain tissue and cerebrosipinal fluid and since it dilates the pial vessels, it is possible that adenosine, in addition to H-+, is also a mediator of the metabolic regulation of cerebral blood flow. Evidence supporting this hypothesis was obtained under various experimental conditions characterized by achange in brain oxygen supply. The brain was frozen in situ by means of a small bonerongeur precooled in liquid N2 and the tissue was processed for adenosine determination (nmol/g of tissue). Electrical stimulation of the cortex at 0, 15, 30, and 45 Hz yielded adenosine levels of 5.4 plus or minus 0.7, 10.5 plus or minus 1.7, 13.0 plusor minus 1.2, and 9.0 plus or minus 2.1 nmol/g. Arterial pressures of 87, 60, and 40mmHg gave adenosine levels of 7.5 plus or minus 0.76, 13 plus or minus 2.6, and 26.6plus or minus 3.3, respectively. Ventilation with 29.7, 20, 10.7, and5.5% O2 significantly increased the adenosine levels to 9.4 plus or minus 3.0, 6.4 plus or minus 1.2, 30.0 plus or minus 9.3, and 63.3 plus or minus 18.2 nmol/g, respectively. Hyperventilation significantly increased adenosine form 6.7 plus or minus 1.0 to 11.8 plus or minus 1.4 nmol/g. This increased adenosine level was reduced by additionof CO2 to the ventilating gas mixture. Lactate, the main H-+ donor, pyruvate, and cAMP changed in a fashion parallel to adenosine. However, cAMP showedonly a small increase in adenosine. These findings are in accordance with the concept that adenosine and H-+ may act synergistally to regulate cerebral blood flow and that endogenous adenosine may exert a small effect on cAMP formation. </jats:p>

title: The Effect of Parenteral Iron Supply on Hematology, Health, Growth and Meat Classification in Veal Calves
OPTIMAL CAPACITIES OF WATER SUPPLY RESERVOIRS IN SERIES AND PARALLEL<sup>1</sup>
container-title: JAWRA Journal of the American Water Resources Association
items.abstract: <jats:p><jats:bold>ABSTRACT: </jats:bold> The planning of water supply reservoirs has traditionally been based on the Rippl or sequent peak analysis which applies to the design of a single reservoir. This paper incorporates the sequent peak method as the central feature in establishing a procedure for determining the sizes of several potential reservoirs located in a system of one or more rivers. Separate algorithms are developed for sites on parallel streams and for sites on the same stream. In both cases the approach is to find the combination of reservoirs which can satisfy a given constant monthly demand at a minimum total construction cost. It is shown that both problems can be cast in the form of a dynamic programming problem. A more complex system is then a combination of reservoirs in parallel and in series. An extension is given if the monthly demand is not constant but each reservoir satisfies a constant fraction of the monthly demand.</jats:p>

title: ChemInform Abstract: STRUCTURAL EFFECTS IN SOLVOLYTIC REACTIONS PART 9, SOLVOLYSIS OF 3‐ARYL‐3‐NORTRICYCLYL P‐NITROBENZOATES, EVIDENCE FOR MAJOR INCREASES IN ELECTRON SUPPLY BY THE CYCLOPROPYL GROUP WITH INCREASING ELECTRON DEMAND AT THE CATIONIC CENTER
